story_text.value:
Hey guys,

As designers and developers, we find the cost of tooling is extremely high and prevent us to iterate: Figma-to-code wall of China, impossible tech stacks, JS dependency hell, project setups more complex than a SpaceX launch.

We've been playing with AI since the GPT3 beta, and found out over the years the biggest obstacle between us and autonomous AI developers is not LLM science, it's this suite of software-based hurdles.

So we're launching Layouts, a notebook-like editor for building interfaces. Just open, describe your interface in a simple syntax, get a production-grade NextJS project repository. Zero setup, zero config, zero headaches.

It's on ProductHunt today: https://www.producthunt.com/posts/layouts-dev

We'd love to get your feedback!

story_text.value:
Hello!

Does anyone had any advice (or guides) on how to transition from messy startup spaghetti code to something more stable and resilient?

I am a young software engineer and don't have much experience. I know about testing and a little bit of devops (containers, etc) but not much.

Most guides I find on the internet are very entry-level. Should I wait till we're profitable enough to hire a senior engineer?

Our stack is React/NextJS/Hasura, but I'm looking for more general advice.

story_text.value:
I have put together an open source repo for demonstrating how to make an LLM web app with NextJS for the frontend, which maintains chat history, API Gateway + Lambda for the logic layer, using the OpenAI API for the LLM.

This is very much a work in progress and most certainly not production ready, but they code will give you a kick start in the right direction. I hope you find it helpful. I intend to keep working it it for my own learning purposes.

story_text.value:
I use pm2, with nginx in front, on a lightsail instance (ubuntu base-image) and manually run commands (clone, migrate, and pm2 restart) every time we merge to a prod branch, with the idea that eventually those commands will run as part of github actions.

The postgres is also on the same instance.

Curious if anyone has any comments on this.

Also a side question if anyone has used coolify for production apps? How was the experience?

I don't want to spend more time than is required maintaining the infra for the webapp.

Can't go with vercel or a hosted PAAS, because we have AWS credits, and don't want to spend unnecessarily.

thanks in advance

title.value: Ask HN: Help with NextJS deployment architecture on AWS

story_text.value:
I’m not a Nextjs user but was looking into whether I want to use it. I noticed that Nextjs 14.0.3 includes a canary build of React.

https://github.com/vercel/next.js/releases/tag/v14.0.3

How in the world is this acceptable? Does the React team maintain an extra branch labeled “canary” just for fun even though it’s actually stable?

Were people who are using this React framework in production right now using React canary before Nextjs?

Assuming the concept of a canary branch still has any meaning, how would a React framework that uses canary React actually be stable?

title.value: Ask HN: How does Nextjs justify using React canary branches?

so we're closing the year , and in 2025 one thing i got tired of was constantly getting feedback from people say "this is not working on the site" and i didnt want to go through all that "sentry" stress , yeah i know sentry isnt difficult to setup , but the dashboard kinda looked too overwhelming and "enterpriseyy" so i built gmail for bugs (basically you see your errors as emails in an inbox) and it takes 4 lines of code to get started

but the interesting part is , ive been able to create the nextjs SDK , and React and nodejs , so i'd recommend the full sdk setup , but the script tag is just a simple way to get started

story_text.value:
Been working in a t3 monorepo and often times tiny ui changes result in having to touch 8-10 different files. Our trpc routes have grown exponentially and each dev is almost adding a new route for each specific feature. We have endpoints that return massive amounts of data fetched by hooks and modifying the prisma query often results in type errors in unrelated files.

I have a strong feeling that something is wrong in our trpc & react query hooks' structure or organization and its severely impacted the dev experience. Does anyone have experience scaling a trpc nextjs application? Are there any code structure or patterns that you use to do trpc the "right" way?

I'm coming from a dotnet / laravel stack and minor ui changes would never have spanned more than 2-3 files. It's hard to find examples of companies using trpc in production and since its new there isn't a lot of info about good practices around it.

title.value: Something is wrong w tRPC and NextJS dx
